title: Roton energy gap and spontaneous symmetry breaking

title_detail.value: Roton energy gap and spontaneous symmetry breaking

summary:
We study elementary excitations in superfluid helium-4 employing an approach
based on the spontaneous symmetry breaking. In particular, we calculate the
roton energy gap at zero temperature $\Delta (0)$. The relation that we have
derived is $\Delta (0) / k_B T_\lambda = 4$. The theoretical value of $\Delta
(0)/k_B$ is 8.707 K, which is significantly close to the experimental value of
8.712 K. The deviation between the theoretical and experimental values is less
than 0.1%.

Roton energy gap and spontaneous symmetry breaking
Junpei Harada∗

arXiv:0911.1599v1 [cond-mat.other] 9 Nov 2009

Niihama National College of Technology, Niihama, 792-8580, Japan
(Dated: November 9, 2009)
We study elementary excitations in superfluid helium-4 employing an approach based on the spontaneous symmetry breaking. In particular, we calculate the roton energy gap at zero temperature
∆(0). The relation that we have derived is ∆(0)/kB Tλ = 4. The theoretical value of ∆(0)/kB is
8.707 K, which is significantly close to the experimental value of 8.712 K. The deviation between
the theoretical and experimental values is less than 0.1%.

The deviation between the theoretical and experimental
values is less than 1%. In this meaning, our approach
succeeded. However, in the previous paper [1], we did
not study the elementary excitations.
Although the roton, which is an elementary excitation
with finite energy gap ∆, has been extensively studied
in the past, its physical nature still remains unclear [3].
In this paper, we calculate the roton energy gap at zero
temperature ∆(0) to understand the physical nature of
roton. First, we calculate the roton energy gap using the
effective potential of the mean field effective field theory.
Second, we introduce the curvature matrix which allows
us to calculate the energy gap directly. The relation that
we have derived is very simple, ∆(0)/kB Tλ = 4. This
relation gives ∆(0)/kB = 8.707 K, which is very close to
the experimental value of 8.712 K. Finally, we comment
on an open problem about the sound speed of phonon. In
the next section, we begin with a brief review of ref. [1]
for self-consistency of this paper.

Before deriving the formula for Tλ , we should see the
spontaneous symmetry breaking. For T > Tλ , the effective potential has only one minimum at φ = 0, and then
the global U (1) symmetry is not broken. For T < Tλ ,
the field φ rolls down from "hill-top" at φ = 0 to the
bottom, and then the global U (1) symmetry is spontaneously broken. This phenomenon is the λ-transition.
The derivation of the formula for Tλ is very easy as follows. When T = 0, the scalar field φ is located at
pthe bottom, and then it takes the nonzero value |φ| = μ(0)/λ.
Hence the global U (1) symmetry is spontaneously broken
in this phase. As the temperature increases above the λtemperature, the scalar field φ is located at φ = 0, and
the global U (1) symmetry is recovered. Therefore, it is
enough that we consider how energy is necessary to take
the scalar field φ from the bottom to "hill-top". From
eq. (3), the depth of the potential V0 is given by

Here we comment on the energy gap of phonon.
Because the coefficient of χ2 term in eq. (16) is zero,
the energy gap of the scalar field χ is exactly zero. This
means that phonon is gapless, and it is a consequence of
the Nambu-Goldstone theorem.

VI.

CONCLUSION

In conclusion, we have calculated the roton energy gap
at zero temperature using an approach based on the
spontaneous symmetry breaking. The relation that we
have derived, ∆(0)/kB Tλ = 4, is in good agreement with
the experimental value. We hope that this work contributes to the progress of low temperature physics.
